factorization

Class Shared_Ranges

  • java.lang.Object
    • factorization.Shared_Ranges

  • public class Shared_Ranges
extends Object
    Contains methods for efficiently representing (or factorizing) the query results of a join between 2 relations where the join condition is an arbitrary number of equalities and a single inequality predicate. The methods rely on sharing the same substructure for numbers that are smaller/larger. The resulting representation creates a number of intermediate layers that can be O(n). The space requirement is also O(n). The running time is O(nlogn) since we sort the relations.
    Author:
    Nikolaos Tziavelis

    • Constructor Detail

      • Shared_Ranges

        public Shared_Ranges()

    • Method Detail

      • factorize_inequality

        public static void factorize_inequality(List<DP_State_Node> left,
                                        List<DP_State_Node> right,
                                        List<Join_Predicate> ps)
        Given two DP stages that correspond to the tuples of two relations and a list that contains many equalities and a single inequality, constructs an efficient representation of the join results. The method relies on creating a hierarchy of nodes where each one is contained in the next.
        Parameters:
        left - The first relation/stage as a list of DP state-nodes.
        right - The second relation/stage as a list of DP state-nodes.
        ps - A list of equality predicates and a single inequality predicate at the end of the list.

      • share_inequality

        private static void share_inequality(List<DP_State_Node> left,
                                     List<DP_State_Node> right,
                                     Join_Predicate inequality)
        A method for encoding the query results of an inequality join. It works by creating a hierarchy of intermediate nodes connected in a chain. Each of those nodes corresponds to a specific range of domain values. Before calling this method, the nodes have to be sorted by the predicate attributes.
        Parameters:
        left - The first (sorted) subset of a relation/stage.
        right - The second (sorted) subset of a relation/stage.
        inequality - A single inequality predicate.
